newsitem.title: FRANCE: EU seen playing safe on wheat after price rise.
newsitem.headline: EU seen playing safe on wheat after price rise.

text.p: European Union decisions effectively scrapping fixed daily refunds for wheat and flour exports indicate that the European Commission will be cautious in the face of volatile prices, a European grain industry source said.
The source, who is familiar with EU export policy, said the Commission wanted to wait to see how markets developed and leave itself free to adapt to the new situation.
"Things are going so fast," the source said, referring to a sudden rise in U.S. wheat prices caused by cold weather and to heavy bidding for wheat and flour in Europe.
The EU on Monday scrapped a fixed daily refund of zero Ecus for wheat and took similar action against a five Ecus refund for flour on Tuesday.
Those items now carry a nil value refund, indicating the value can change again before shipment.
"We are in for a very difficult few weeks," the source said, adding it was too early to say what the EU would do at its weekly tender for wheat exports.
But grain traders said the latest EU's moves suggested that the 1996/97 export campaign was drawing very quickly to an end.
The grain source, however, dismissed market talk that traders wishing to guarantee cover for remaining commitments could offer to pay an export tax at this Thursday's tender.
Under current EU regulations such offers would be invalid, the source said.
Traders holding previously issued refunds of zero Ecus can use them for new crop sales up to the end of August.

On Tuesday exporters bid through France to export 217,000 tonnes of soft wheat under nil value licences and 214,500 tonnes of flour under licences carrying a five Ecus per tonne rebate, national grain office ONIC said.
A European industry source said there were bids for 400,000 tonnes of flour across the EU as a whole. -- Paris newsroom 6331 4221 5432
